Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: A Timing Perspective on Information Dissemination in Vehicular Adhoc Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the theoretical foundations for vehicular ad hoc networks (VANETs), which have emerged as a radically new paradigm for the design of networking protocols, mobility models, and a variety of new applications. This technology has its roots in on-board sensors in vehicles, global position systems (GPS) receivers, and algorithms/protocols for ad hoc networks, which enable vehicle-to-vehicle communications without infrastructure equipment (e.g., base stations in cellular systems). A fundamental yet open issue is addressed: how rapidly and efficiently can information be disseminated in a vehicular ad hoc network? To address the unique challenges presented by mobility-induced time dynamics, a complimentary approach of networking analysis and physical channel exploitation is employed.

The project focuses on three issues: (1) Development and analysis of new measures of connection times among vehicles in percolated VANETs, in contrast to traditional measures of network connectivity. (2) Exploration of the impact of fading-induced channel variation on network performance and development of new fading prediction-aided routing mechanisms that integrate adaptive transmission techniques, e.g. rate and relay selection. (3) Identification of the theoretical time limits of information dissemination and capacity-delay trade-offs when nodes move at high speeds and in highly dynamic vehicular networks.

As vehicular communications advance large-scale and social networks, this project addresses an acute and timely demand for exploring fundamental principles of mobility-induced channels and network dynamics, which have not been studied systematically, but have tremendous impact on routing protocol designs, optimization techniques for performance analysis and estimation, and modeling of network architecture and topology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have studied the fundamental limits of  information  dissemination in high speed vehicular networks and open issues in the current understanding of mobility-induced time dynamics and to develop a set of simple yet effective algorithms and protocols motivated by our findings. Our approach is to take a timing-perspective and examine the impact of moving vehicles on network topology (not fully connected), time-varying channels, relay selection etc., and to directly exploit them to the benefit of judicious choice of routing metrics and scheduling, as opposed to using off-line cross-layer parameters vectors and optimal assumptions of relay placement and routing.

To achieve our objectives, we have used a set of theories, such as information theory, physical channel modeling, graph theory, percolation theory, in combination of statistic analysis by developing sensing schemes, medium access control protocols, new models and metrics of inter-node mobility, and evaluation based on real traces. We have found that (1) The channel stat information (CSI) can be used in aiding medium access control when cognitive radios are available, and thus throughput and quality of received signal can be greatly improved; (2) all mobile vehicles have temporal and spatial correlations, which can be analyzed based on their social and communication locality, which in turn, can benefit routing, scheduling, and system performance; (3)  Based on active message mobility, we derive lower and upper bounds for the farthest distance that messages reach at a certain time and the first time that messages reach distance d from the source location, which can not only give the theoretical limits of emergenet message propagation, but also facilitate many existing algorithms like stateless opportunistic forwarding (SOF) and and GPS-based broadcasting (GBB) in applications such as post-crash warning with preferrable parameters and interested contents sharing.
